Following up on my module title question from yesterday, this is Ubercart-specific (hi @Laryn); but is generally applicable to contrib modules that extend other contrib modules (e.g., Webform add-ons).

Having just finished my second Ubercart module port (and more on the way), I'm wondering about standards for Ubercart-related module naming in Backdrop.

Most of the Backdrop Ubercart contrib modules are currently named "Ubercart Something". Whereas over on the Drupal side, most are just called "Something", and a few are called "UC Something". This makes me wonder:

1) For modules created solely for Backdrop Ubercart (no D7 port), is there a preferred naming scheme?

2) For modules ported from D7, should the name be exactly what it was in D7 (modulo capitalization standardization), or should it be adjusted to follow a preferred/consistent naming scheme (i.e., add or remove "Ubercart" or "UC" to/from the name)?

Then there's the question of which package the contrib module should belong to.

3) Should the package name for an Ubercart contrib module be one of the non-core Ubercart package names already defined by the Ubercart modules (i.e., "Ubercart - extra", "Ubercart - fulfillment", "Ubercart - payment"), or a specific separate name (e.g., "Ubercart - contrib"), or are there no particular recommendations?

4) Whatever the answers to 1–3 are, would it be a good idea to document that information on the Ubercart project Wiki page (which I'd be happy to draft)?

backdrop-contrib/ubercart
A flexible but easy-to-use e-commerce system for Backdrop. - backdrop-contrib/ubercart

Thanks @bugfolder++ for porting these modules over :pray: ...I think that as long as the machine name of the module stays the same as the respective 7.x version, then the module name (human-readable label) should be fine to deviate from the D7 version. It would be nice to bring some consistency to the Ubercart ecosystem of modules in Backdrop-land though...
bugfolder great work (Karma: 5)

...to that end (consistency), I think that you should be aware that we are considering to remove the grouping in the module listing page at some point: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/3148 (although inactive for some time now)

Describe your issue or idea This is a follow-up to #37 to un-block that issue. PR by @klonos: backdrop/backdrop#2548
...if (when?) that happens, it would be helpful to have the "Ubercart" bit prepended to the module names.
...having "Ubercart" as a name prefix would also help in the module list in https://backdropcms.org/modules
Do you think that should apply to just Ubercart add-on modules, or also to all of the Ubercart core modules?

Well, Ubercart core won't have any issue with https://backdropcms.org/modules since only the main project is listed - not any submodules it includes. As for the module listing in the admin UI, they would need to specify their "parent" module in their names I think.
...perhaps Ubercart: Core: Some Module or Ubercart: Category: Some Contrib Module would be helpful :shrug:

The base Ubercart distribution has something like 27 submodules, none of which currently contain "Ubercart" in their name on the module listing (other than the main Ubercart module). They have names like "Flat rate", "Weight quote", and so forth.
Well, I think that if they are not generic modules, then they should be denoting the module they work with, which they require and extend.

@bugfolder I've had some questions about this, too. Ubercart in particular has so many sub-modules that it brings all the issues to the surface pretty quickly... I think adding "Ubercart" to all the submodule names directly would be pretty visually heavy/unwieldy and would personally prefer a way to still group them or at least indicate a belonging without manually adding the group/package name directly in the module name. (e.g. a smaller subtle package indicator and a filter on the project page, even if they aren't sorted into packages by default)

Just did a little further looking into this as it has been a while and the "small subtle package indicator" may be what tags are for... I have not tested yet if we do end up removing project groupings whether adding "Ubercart" as a tag in the .info file for a module would be enough to be able to use the filter at the top of the project page by typing "Ubercart" rather than having to have Ubercart listed directly in the module name.

Whatever the answers to 1–3 are, would it be a good idea to document that information on the Ubercart project Wiki page (which I'd be happy to draft)?

Yes, but I suppose we need to answer 1-3 first. :smile:

It does kinda seem like package groupings serve the role of keeping related things together. Tags would do that even better (since even Ubercart core is spread over multiple packages). It would be nice if the Backdrop Modules page offered tags as a separate filter from the general search box (which returns some non-Ubercart modules even if one enters "Ubercart").
Also some indication of what the existing .info tags are, to encourage developers to apply existing tags if appropriate.

Agreed. See also: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/3147

Related, yet unrelated, long term I would like to see:

a) Ubercart renamed. This trademark was created under a company that hired Ryan Szrama to create an ecommerce platform. I believe they still own ubercart.org.

OR

b) Ubercart forked into a future evolving platform. UC is old and dated and needs work to bring it up to relevant standards.

I'll note, I am not a fan of Commerce and have zero plans of ever using it.
Is "Ubercart" really trademarked?

@Laryn in the US, technically any "name" that has been used in commerce is automatically trademarked. How far the owning entity wants to go to protect that trademark, is solely upto the entity. A registered trademark says the entity out-right owns it and had the power to easily fight it.
I don't know who "technically" owns the mark, but I do know it was created under the guise of the company that paid for the work to have UC created.
There was some discussion last week or over the weekend to "distinguish BD from Drupal". This is one area I think BD could distinguish itself away from it's big brother.

ubercart.org is owned by: Prima, LLC out of Kentucky. I'm not 100% sure, but I believe it is: https://primasupply.com/ which is clearly no longer using Drupal or Ubercart. I think it's safe to use Ubercart as the name, but I'm of the opinion it's time to update Ubercart, make it its own and distance away from its origins.

Just my own personal thoughts on the matter. (Long term goals)

@docwilmot if github is doing things the way I think they are with webhooks, then yes you should be able to set it up on your local dev.

From my understanding, you have a listener that listens for intents sent by an endpoint. If it hears that intent, it does something with it.

As long as the endpoint can reach the internet (not blocked by an apache .htaccess password login for example) then anything can be configured as an endpoint.

My terminology might be a little off but in essence, instead of sending a file with information like XML or json, you send a machine name (intent) to the listener. If the listener sees (hears) it, it checks authenticity through the token and routes it to the appropriate account based on the API key.

It's a way to send real-time information over the wire without having to send a bunch of files every time something needs to be done.

I want to say it can be asynchronous as well, but I'm fuzzy on that part.
This makes me realize that the Telemetry initiative @StPaulTim is working on might be a good candidate for webhooks. Telemetry data could possibly be updated in real-time.
